election_record.label: Pennsylvania 1796 Electoral College

overview.note: The New World lists the name William Irwin for William Irvine, and uses the spelling Elliot for Benjamin Elliott.
Kline's Carlisle Weekly Gazette (Carlisle, PA) uses the spelling Smiley for John Smilie.

The Franklin Repository (Chambersburg, PA), Gazette of the United States, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), and Claypoole's Daily American Advertiser list the name William Irwin for William Irvine, and use the spelling Douglass for Ephraim Douglas.

Die Unpartheyische York Gazette (York, PA) (York, PA) uses the spellings Hannah for James Hannah, Irwin for William Irvine, Maclay for William McClay, Eliot for Benjamin Elliott, Schmith for Abraham Smith, and Herzel for Jonas Hartzell.
Thomas McKean headed the Jefferson ticket. Israel Whelen headed the Adams ticket.

Because the Greene County returns were late in reporting and could not legally be counted, two of the Adams electors were chosen. The return for Greene County was later reported to be: For Jefferson 210; For Adams 44. These returns from Greene County when added to the above results as stated in the Official Proclamation would then give the candidates that headed each slate the following votes: Thomas McKean 12,516 and Israel Whelen 12,229. It should be noted, that had Greene County returns arrived in time to be counted in Official Proclamation, the entire Jefferson slate of Electors would have been choosen.

"Pennsylvania law required all returns for presidential electors to be sent to the governor's office within fourteen days of the election and that the governor proclaim the results. By the date due, 18 Nov. 1796, however, the counties of Fayette, Greene, and Westmoreland had sent no returns, and both Federalists and Republicans were claiming victory in a very close contest. Since the law made no provision for such circumstances, Gov. Thomas Mifflin referred his dilemma to the attorney general and the Supreme Court judges of Pennsylvania. They advised delay until 23 Nov., but even by then the delinquent returns had not arrived. The results for Fayette and Westmoreland counties appeared the next day, and on that basis Mifflin decided to announce that Republican candidates had won thirteen of the state's fifteen presidential electors, a decision vigorously protested by the Federalists. The officially proclaimed electors cast their votes in Harrisburg on 7 Dec. 1796, and two days later Mifflin defended his conduct in his address to Pennsylvania legislature." The Papers of James Madison, 429.

"Yesterday's mail brought the returns of Westmoreland and Fayette. The delay in the receipt of these returns is said to have arisen from their being sent from Greensburgh, where they were deposited for transmission, to Pittsburg, instead of Philadelphia, and arriving in Pittsburg subsequent to the day on which the Pittsburg mail for Philadelphia is closed, a delay of a week was produced." The New World. November 25, 1796.

sub_unit.name: Allegheny
sub_unit.note: The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 395 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 69 votes for the Adams ticket.

sub_unit.name: Bedford
sub_unit.note: The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 18 votes for the Adams ticket.
The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 10 votes for the Adams ticket.

sub_unit.name: Berks
sub_unit.note: The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 793 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 710 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
Gazette of the United States, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 716 votes for the Jefferson ticket.

sub_unit.name: Bucks
sub_unit.note: "In Bucks, James Edgar lost above 300 votes, John Edgar was voted for through mistake." The New World (Philadelphia, PA). November 17, 1796.
The New World (Philadelphia, PA) reports 361 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 361 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
Washington Gazette reports 361 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
The Western Telegraphe, and Washington Advertiser (Washington, PA) reports 361 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 359 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 359 votes for the Jefferson ticket.

sub_unit.name: Chester
sub_unit.note: Lancaster Journal (Lancaster, PA) reports 533 votes for the Adams ticket.
Gazette of the United States, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 535 votes for the Adams ticket.

Gazette of the United States, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), Claypoole's Daily American Advertiser, and Gales's Independent Gazetteer (Philadelphia, PA) report 122 votes for Thomas McKean.

sub_unit.name: Cumberland
sub_unit.note: The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 749 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 251 votes for the Adams ticket.
Gazette of the United States, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 749 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 251 votes for the Adams ticket.
Claypoole's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 858 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
Kline's Carlisle Weekly Gazette reports 853 votes for the Jefferson ticket in Cumberland County. It reports 853 votes for Thomas McKean.
The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 853 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
Gales's Independent Gazetteer (Philadelphia, PA) reports 858 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
The New World (Philadelphia, PA) reports 858 votes for the Jefferson ticket.

sub_unit.name: Dauphin
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 435 votes for the Adams ticket.
The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 466 votes for the Adams ticket.
Gazette of the United States, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 234 votes for the Jefferson ticket.

sub_unit.name: Delaware
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 127 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 312 votes for the Adams ticket.
The New World (Philadelphia, PA) reports 184 votes for the Jefferson ticket.
Gales's Independent Gazetteer (Philadelphia, PA) reports 213 votes for the Adams ticket.

sub_unit.name: Franklin
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 344 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 246 votes for the Adams ticket.
The Franklin Repository (Chambersburg, PA) reports 344 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 246 votes for the Adams ticket.
The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 345 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 246 votes for the Adams ticket.
Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 249 votes for the Adams ticket.
Gazette of the United States, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 234 votes for the Adams ticket and 256 votes for the Jefferson ticket.

sub_unit.name: Greene
sub_unit.note: The votes from Greene County were reported too late and therefore not included in the Official Proclamation.

sub_unit.name: Lancaster
sub_unit.note: "In Lancaster, but 14 names were on the Jefferson ticket, William Brown was omitted." The New World (Philadelphia, PA).

sub_unit.name: New Holland
sub_unit.note: The New World, Gazette of the United States, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), Gales's Independent Gazetteer (Philadelphia, PA), Claypoole's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), and The Herald of the Times. Or, the Luzerne Impartial Gazette (Wilkes-Barre, PA) report 80 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 490 votes for the Adams ticket.

sub_unit.name: Upper Cross Roads
sub_unit.note: Upper Cross Roads is also referred to as Donegal District.

sub_unit.name: Mifflin
sub_unit.note: "In this county there was a very unequal vote. Two names on the Jefferson ticket had but 400 votes. Two names on the Adams ticket had 67 votes." The New World (Philadelphia, PA). November 17, 1796.

"One or more districts of Mifflin, whose vote was decidedly in favour of the Jefferson ticket, were not admitted into the general return for the County, on account of not having been received within the time prescribed by law." The New World (Philadelphia, PA). November 25, 1796.
The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 469 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 27 votes for the Adams ticket.
The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 469 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 67 votes for the Adams ticket.
Gazette of the United States, and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 469 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 67 votes for the Adams ticket.

sub_unit.name: Montgomery
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 332 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 532 votes for the Adams ticket.

sub_unit.name: Northampton
sub_unit.note: Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) and Virginia Gazette, November 9, report 459 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 383 votes for the Adams ticket in Northampton County. November 9, 1796.

"The following returns (partial) from Northampton County we extract from a letter ... The letter writer adds, that it is excepted (sic) that Jefferson will have ultimately a majority of about 90 votes in Northampton County." Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA). November 9, 1796.

sub_unit.name: Northumberland
sub_unit.note: The returns for Lycoming County are included in those from Northumberland County.

"Correct information from Northumberland and Lycoming, states that one district in Lycoming was not received in time. In this district there was a small majority for the Adams ticket. In one district of Northumberland there was no election, and in another the votes given were rejected from being added up in figures, and not in words as the law directs. In this district there is said to have been a majority of about one hundred for Adams ticket." The New World (Philadelphia, PA). November 14, 1796.
Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 754 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 30 votes for the Adams ticket.
The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 754 votes for the Jefferson ticket and 30 votes for the Adams ticket.
Gales's Independent Gazetteer (Philadelphia, PA) reports 71 votes for the Adams ticket.
The New World (Philadelphia, PA) reports 71 votes for the Adams ticket.
The Philadelphia Gazette and Universal Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 71 votes for the Adams ticket.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: Gales's Independent Gazetteer (Philadelphia, PA) reports a total of 1735 votes for Thomas McKean.

The Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) lists Joseph Heister with 1732 votes, John Piper with 1729 votes, William MacClay with 1733 votes, Jonas Hartzell with 1729 votes, Robert Coleman with 1089 votes, William Wilson with 1082 votes, John Carson with 1086 votes and Thomas Stokely with 1084 votes.
